condition.name: Intoxicated
entries: An intoxicated creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. To cast a spell, the creature must first succeed a DC 10 Constitution check. Otherwise, the spellcasting action is wasted, but the spell is not.

language.name: Adalindian Whistling
entries: A secret, whistled language used by the Gnomish resistance movement {@link Hand of Adalind|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/hand-of-adalind-kFepjGY6vb}.

language.name: Tribal
entries: Tribal is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants used mostly by the {@race Tribeborn|dungeonchurch} of the southwest. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

entries.name: Age
entries: The Elfmarked mature at the same rate humans do and reach adulthood around the age of 20. They live much longer than humans, however, often exceeding 180 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: The Elfmarked are about the same size as humans, ranging from 5 to 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your elven heritage, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Elven Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Skill Versatility
entries: You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and two extra languages of your choice.
According to superstitions common in the villages, children who exhibit certain talents, deformities, or spurious lineage are called {@i Children of the Travelers} a.k.a. the elfmarked.

Many stories - or convenient excuses - of individuals being charmed into illicit encounters with elves have been reported over the centuries. Sometimes the rumors claim whole towns were bewitched into bacchanal acts, or driven mad in carnivals beyond comprehension, only to find themselves not only hungover - but bearing a generation of progeny that can only be called special.
More skeptical minds consider these children to have been exposed to magic in the womb, or to be the resurgence of recessive traits from pre-human species lost to the cycle of time.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Elfmarked in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/elfmarked-ohkfCOb0aT}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Ravenfolk reach adulthood at 10 years old, and can live to be 110.

entries.name: Size
entries: Ravenfolk are slighter and shorter than humans. They range from 4 feet to just shy of 6 feet tall. Your size is Small or Medium.

entries.name: Sudden Attack
entries: You have advantage on attack rolls against a surprised creature.

entries.name: Mimicry
entries: Ravenfolk can mimic any sound they've heard. Make a Charisma {@skill Deception} check against the passive {@skill Insight} of any listeners. Success indicates they believe the sound you created was real.

entries.name: Trickster
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Deception} and {@skill Stealth} skills.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can mimic Common perfectly and 3 additional languages poorly.

Few live amid so much rumor, suspicion, and outright falsehood as the ravenfolk. Depending on whom you ask, they might condemn the ravenfolk as nomads bearing misfortune or praise them as messengers from the gods. Ravenfolk are loyal comrades and treacherous thieves, brave warriors and contemptible cowards. They are despised for their strange and secretive nature, and criticized for having no true culture - only mimicry. These contradictions conceal a greater mystery few understand or know.

The Ravenfolk are the ethereal wanderers and messengers of Pyora, born from the celestial drama of deities and their caprices. They emerged from the feathers of {@link Eve|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/eve-QQyGI5YbZc}, the winged consort of the {@deity Raven Queen|pyora|dungeonchurch}, who, in a fit of jealousy clipped Eve's wings to keep her faithful. These feathers, cast into the nether regions of the planes, took on life and consciousness, becoming the {@race Ravenfolk|dungeonchurch}.
Cast out from their home, the Ravenfolk traverse the myriad planes of existence, seeking redemption and a path back to the favor of the Raven Queen.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Ravenfolk in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ravenfolk-2FqUStq1FR}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Tribeborn mature a little faster than humans, reaching adulthood around age 14. They age noticeably faster and rarely live longer than 75 years.

entries.name: Size
entries: Tribeborn are somewhat larger and bulkier than humans, and they range from 5 to well over 6 feet tall. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Thanks to your tribal upbringing, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Tribal Resilience
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Survival}

entries.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can't use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon's damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Tribal. Tribal is a harsh, grating language with hard consonants. It has no script of its own but is written in the Dwarvish script.

The Tribeborn are a formidable and resilient people, born of the union between orcs and other species. Deeply connected to their tribal settlements in the wilderness of the southwestern jungles, they embody a fusion of the primal strength of their orcish heritage with the varied traits of Pyora's diversity.

Tribeborn often inherit the physical prowess and stature of orcs, characterized by robust builds and distinct features such as prominent jaws and tusk-like teeth. Their skin tones range from deep greens to earthy browns, often marked with tribal tattoos or scars from rites of passage.

Tribeborn are deeply communal, valuing the bonds of their tribe above all. They are raised with a strong sense of loyalty and often act as protectors of their people and the wild lands they call home. Their communities are tight-knit, with traditions and customs passed down through generations.
They are not common in the urban cities of Pyora, preferring to live apart from broader society.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Tribeborn in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/tribeborn-KVgPsdxk3f}.

Forged by the {@link First Dragon Emperor|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragon-empire-odzVqtQPbm#h-emperors} as an unholy magical corruption of humanity, the slaves that conquered and then built the First Empire.
Finally freed of their wyrm master, the former conscripts have since proven their resilience and independent nature despite lingering doubts about their true allegiances.

Many of the dispossessed dragonborn have been instrumental in reclaiming the abandoned dwarven port of {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t} and building a thriving free city where it is said, 'every man a king.'
Others have sought to create a new history and culture that they were denied, living tribal lives in the wilderness.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dragonborn in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dragonborn-pyoran-Pd8mdtKo6V}.

entries.name: Artificer's Lore
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence {@skill History} check related to magic items, alchemical objects, or technological devices, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

entries.name: Stone Tea
entries: You have proficiency with {@item Gnomish Tea Set|dungeonchurch}. Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of the Stone Tea brew, and an individual with a week's preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, Stone Tea is known to induce erratic behavior individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

entries.name: Tinker
entries: You have proficiency with {@item tinker's tools|phb}. Using those tools, you can spend 1 hour and 10 gp worth of materials to construct a Tiny clockwork device (AC 5, 1 hp). The device ceases to function after 24 hours (unless you spend 1 hour repairing it to keep the device functioning), or when you use your action to dismantle it; at that time, you can reclaim the materials used to create it. You can have up to three such devices active at a time.
When you create a device, choose one of the following options:

entries.name: Clockwork Toy
entries: This toy is a clockwork animal, monster, or person, such as a frog, mouse, bird, dragon, or soldier. When placed on the ground, the toy moves 5 feet across the ground on each of your turns in a random direction. It makes noises as appropriate to the creature it represents.

entries.name: Fire Starter
entries: The device produces a miniature flame, which you can use to light a candle, torch, or campfire. Using the device requires your action.

entries.name: Music Box
entries: When opened, this music box plays a single song at a moderate volume. The box stops playing when it reaches the song's end or when it is closed.

The diminutive little people, gnomes live below ground and guard their homeland with a jealous secrecy that few have glimpsed. Their dealings with the civilizations above ground is limited to trade, where they are known for intricate craftsmanship and ingenious devices. Some gnomes have come to live on the surface and assimilate to human life - known as halflings - as in half-humans.

The gnomes are masters of the tea ceremony, and it is rare to find even a halfling on the surface who does not travel with their tea set. While most are made of metal because of it's durability, each tea set is handcrafted and unique to the person. Some are highly polished works of art, others are more functional in nature and so modified over the years by their user they more resemble some type of clockwork.

Gnomes of the Underdark are known to use their tea sets in communal rituals that allow them to {@spell Stone Shape} en masse. If enough gnomes participate in this ritual, they can effectively tunnel and travel through solid stone. The exact nature of this Stone Tea and it's ceremony are a tightly guarded gnomish secret.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Rock Gnomes in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gnome-rock-ARFvDASnZz}.

entries.name: Brisk Footed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Stone Marcher
entries: When you take the {@action Dash} action in mountainous or hilly environments, non-magical difficult terrain doesn't cost you extra movement on that turn.

The dwarves of the Kingdom's diaspora are collectively known as hearth dwarves. Wherever they have made their homes in the lands of Pyora, what separates them from their brethren is that they live their lives, raise families, and explore the world outside the influence of the current Prophet-King in Durandar.

Many are found in port towns, where they settled incidentally along migration routes. Others never left the sea, and pledge their lives to the hearthship of their confederates rather than follow the faithful underground. Some are outcasts or seekers - sorcerers and wizards who must search for arcane knowledge outside the unsupportive dwarven guild system.

They tend to follow dwarven customs in one way or another, mixed with the local flavor of wherever they find themselves. Just as many hold to the old prophecies as those who kneel to the new gods. These dwarves are fond of formalizing their chosen clans as businesses, settlements, communes, companies, and pirate ships - their 'hearths' - which more often than not include non-dwarves.

Despite their independent nature and varied experiences, whatever wanderlust drives them to seek fortune and community on their own also gives them a reputation for being fiercely loyal to those they choose for friends.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Hearth Dwarves in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dwarf-hearth-JqwmFsdhFj}.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered apprentices in Durandar until they reach the age of 100. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Durandian Ingenuity
entries: You are proficient in two {@item artisan's tools|phb}, due to the Kingdom's emphasize on craft and trades. You may alternately choose one {@item musical instrument|phb} to be proficient instead.

entries.name: Kingdom Training
entries: All dwarves in the kingdom are trained in basic martial arts. You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer}. You also have proficiency with light and medium armor.

It's taken centuries for {@link King Olfgard Wisebeard|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-olfgard-wisebeard-S0YDu9xGHy} to convince the majority of the dwarven tribes to abandon their homes and build the new granite city of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} under the mountain. Opposed to the use of magic, the dwarves there dedicate themselves to alchemy & artificing, building great forges, damming the power of the rivers, and preparing for the apocalypse that's been foretold.

But dwarves are stubborn & not everyone has gone along. Some have stayed behind, adapting to the flood of newcomers to the old cities, while others have sought fortune on the continent as independent merchants or hireswords.
It is rumored that the pirates who plague {@link Striborg's merchant ships|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-navy-ndvIs6jZtX} are dwarves who prefer the open sea.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Dwarves in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dwarf-durandian-UOdggQRi6Y}.

entries.name: Jack of all Trades
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice. You gain one feat of your choice.
The most common species by far, humans have built their cities, expanded their roads, and in general sought order in the world.

Human ambition is embodied in the prosperous merchant city of {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV}. Ruled by an aristocratic merchant class, with a rising religious-populous movement in the streets, Striborg has become a place increasingly unwelcome to those not committed to human partisanship in some form.

Most humans do not live in Striborg though, but in simple settlements throughout the continent. These people are driven by more basic motivations: farmers, craftsmen, travelers, scholars, and adventurers.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Humans in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/human-pyoran-LMuc7qNrv4}.

entries.name: Stone Tea
entries: You have proficiency with {@item Gnomish Tea Set|dungeonchurch}. Gnomes and halflings who come from Underdark society know the secret of the Stone Tea brew, and an individual with a week's preparation time and the proper ingredients can summon enough magic to imbue a single tea ceremony ritual with {@spell Stone Shape}. However, Stone Tea is known to induce erratic behavior individuals who are regularly exposed to sunlight.

The diminutive little people, gnomes live below ground and guard their homeland with a jealous secrecy that few have glimpsed. their dealings with the civilizations above ground is limited to trade, where they are known for intricate craftsmanship and ingenious devices.

Some gnomes have come to live on the surface and assimilate to human life - known as halflings - as in half-humans. These people tend to be nomadic and independent, with an intrinsic wanderlust that led them out of the Underdark and away from their traditional culture and lifestyle underground.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Halflings in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/halfling-fFZiVbQDbC}.

deity.name: Abraxas
deity.title: God of War
deity.symbol: Rooster whipping a dragon, Scale encircled by Whip
entries: God of war and martial classes, patron of {@link Iron Riders of Abraxas|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-riders-of-abraxas-P77pTaxjou}, slayer of dragons. He is said to be the neutral arbiter of the other gods, instilling justice in the planes with his whip.
Many call on him to witness their oaths, in hope of currying his favor (and wrath) if the other party does not hold up their end.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Abraxas in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/abraxas-uKXAkU30vX}.

deity.name: Anhon
deity.title: God of the Sun
entries: This god of summer takes the form of a young man. He is inhumanly tall and has a wide-chested build. Anhon has short yellow hair, narrow brown eyes, and tan skin. He is usually portrayed as wearing a flattering costume that is mostly scarlet in color. Anhon wears a gold bracelet of intricate geometric design and carries a compass. Anhon is occasionally precocious with a neutral alignment.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Anhon in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/anhon-NB2cmmeCOh}.

deity.name: Azrael
deity.title: The Pathfinder
deity.symbol: Black Candle, Rainbows, Hooded Rider or Ferryman
entries: A hooded figure, wreathed in dark mist, carrying a scroll upon which the name of every living being is written at birth, a black candle floats behind its head, the spectral flame slowly cycling through every hue in the spectrum.

Sometimes appears as a rider atop a blindfolded stallion the color of the void, other times as a ferryman guiding a barge constructed from the ribs of a giant, lashed together by slowly-writhing, oily sinew.

To look within the hood is to behold endless cosmos, a vision so terrible one can never again turn their gaze to anything else, as they join the Pathfinder on their final journey from this mortal realm, and their name is erased from its scroll.
Patron of scribes, alchemists and cupbearers, often associated with cats, owls, lost coins and cloudless nights.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Azrael in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/azrael-ENK1L9l9rm}.

deity.name: Ostara
deity.title: The Trickster
deity.symbol: Triangle, Hares, Things that come in Threes
entries: Goddess of the changing seasons who represents uncontrollable wild places, hedonistic pleasure, the weather, and the domain between reality and illusion. Ostara is predictably unreliable, a force for both good & evil that often comes too early or too late, and usually in the form of tricks or riddles.

As opposed to the orderly chaotic good of {@link Selune|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba} who controls the rhythm of the moon and tides in the night, Ostara is true chaos that straddles the line between dreams and the light of dawn - it's never clear if her attention is for favor or for ill. Possibly, it's both.

It is said in legends when she appears as a human (always just before dawn), she takes the form of an ageless blonde with a gossamer dress made from frost, riding either a hare or a nightingale, disappearing at first light.
A common superstition is: Seeing a hare or a nightingale on a journey is considered either a good or bad omen, depending on the circumstances.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Ostara in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/ostara-pPhCdlIg9G}.

deity.name: Proteus
deity.title: God of the Sea
entries: God of the seas who is said to hold the key to the ocean and thus power over all living things. His domain is the eternal, the ancient unknown, and stability - the rock lost sailors cling to. His beard is longer than time and changes shapes as often as the waves.

He is engaged in a never ending struggle with the cycle of the tides, as each night {@link Selune's|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba} waves pull the oceans apart and and spread madness and change throughout the world.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Proteus in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/proteus-Apiz4CreFn}.

deity.name: Raven Queen
deity.title: Goddess of Death
entries: A deity who rules in the ethereal fey magic of the far planes.

The Raven Queen, a deity shrouded in mystery, presides over the moment of transition between life and death. Her followers believe she is the guardian of the line between the living and the dead, watching over all those souls who cross it's boundary. In Pyora, she is often associated with bad omens or bad luck.

The Raven Queen was once a powerful sorceress whose jealousy led her to a fateful act against her lover, {@link Eve|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/eve-QQyGI5YbZc}. In a singular moment of possessive rage, she clipped Eve's wings, scattering the feathers across the planes where they transformed into the {@race Ravenfolk|dungeonchurch}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link the Raven Queen in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/raven-queen-95zkXkC4gg}.

deity.name: Sel√ªne
deity.title: Mother of Madness
entries: Goddess of the moon. Hers was the moon's mysterious power, the heavenly force that governed the world's tides and a mother's reproductive cycles, caused lycanthropes to shift form, and drew one to the brink of madness, and back again.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Selune in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/selune-wFfmk6l5Ba}.

deity.name: Siduri
deity.title: The Beer Runner
entries: Siduri is often depicted as a dwarf with a warm, inviting demeanor and a flowing beard adorned with jewels and hop vines, which are sacred to her. Their attire is vibrant and ever-changing, reflecting her fluid identity and the transformative nature of their domain.

In dwarven legends, Siduri was a crafty revolutionary who attempted a failed coup against the King. Imprisoned and waiting to be put to death, they escaped when the guards drank too much ale and fell asleep. Cursed to be on the run for eternity, Siduri grew a beard and changes identities to keep ahead of fate.

Siduri governs over fermentation, revelry, transformation, and joy. They are the patron of brewers, vintners, artists, thieves, and all who seek the joyful liberation found in festive gatherings or revolutions. Their name is invoked to ensure the success of crops used in brewing, the battle cries of rebels, and blessed as the host of many a joyful gathering.

Siduri's most fervent followers are known to devote themselves to revolutionary causes of any and all types, no matter the grievance. A large part of their worship is organizing surreal parties, spontaneous parades, and theater troupes that transgress the taboo and occasionally veer into riots. For this reason, their temples and chapels are often persecuted or banned in large cities - widely seen as dangerous front groups for radical elements.

magicvariant.name: Durandian-Crafted Bow
entries: The forgemasters of Durandar are known for the quality of their craft.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
The forgemasters of Durandar are known for the quality of their craft.
You gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

magicvariant.name: Durandian-Forged Blade
entries: The forgemasters of Durandar are known for the quality of their craft.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
The forgemasters of Durandar are known for the quality of their craft.
You gain a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The cat has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Returning
entries: A returning weapon allows you to hurl the weapon in such a way that it returns to you. When you attack with a returning weapon, if you roll an even number on the {@dice d20}, the weapon returns to you by the end of your turn. You can catch the weapon if you have a hand free to do so. If not, the weapon lands at a random point within 5 feet of you. If you roll an odd number on the {@dice d20} for the attack roll, the weapon fails to return to you.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h} 5 ({@dice 1d6+2}) slashing damage.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the briar tree remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal tree.

trait.name: Thorny Defense
entries: A creature that touches the briar tree or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Lightning Absoprtion
entries: Whenever the briar mound would take lightning damage, it instead takes no damage and regains hit points equal to the damage dealt.

trait.name: Thorny Defense
entries: A creature that touches the briar mound or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@dice 2d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The briar mound makes two attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The briar mound engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 14} saving throw at the start of each of the briar mound's turns or take 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the briar mound moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The briar mound can have only one creature engulfed at a time.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The shark has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The clockwork shark doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The clockwork shark is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The clockwork shark has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 0 ft, one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 5d6}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) force damage.

monster.name: Coal Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Ignite
entries: When the Coal Golem would take fire damage from any source, it is lit aflame for 1 minute. While set aflame it casts a bright light 20ft and dim light another 20ft. In addition, whenever a creature hits (or is hit by) the golem with a melee attack, they suffer {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Slow {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem targets one or more creatures it can see within 10 feet of it. Each target must make a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw against this magic. On a failed save, a target can't use reactions, its speed is halved, and it can't make more than one attack on its turn. In addition, the target can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, not both. These effects last for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the dire boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the dire boar takes 10 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Survival Instinct
entries: The dire boar has advantage on Survival (Wisdom) checks.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The dire boar has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dire boar makes two attacks with it's tusks.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Escape
entries: The dire hare can take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The dire hare has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the dire hare moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its bite on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

reaction.name: Infestation
entries: If the dire hare is hit with a melee attack, all creatures within 5 ft. of the hare must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or they are covered with a {@creature Swarm of Insects|mm|Swarm of Fleas}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} saving throw against disease or become {@condition poisoned}

trait.name: Ignite
entries: When the Giant Coal Ant would take fire damage from any source, it is lit aflame for 1 minute. While set aflame it casts a bright light 20ft and dim light another 20ft. In addition, whenever a creature hits (or is hit by) the ant with a melee attack, they suffer {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The giant ant has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant ant makes one Bite attack and one Sting attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the giant ant can't Bite a different target.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage. The target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Giant Coal Ant in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/giant-coal-ant-M9repJEaQW}.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the hellion's darkvision.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The hellion doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hellion has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hellion makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its fork

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fork
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rebellious Tongue
entries: If the hellion did not Bite this turn, it may use {@spell Vicious Mockery}.

entries.name: Tormented Souls
entries: Hellions are the souls of children who died in torment or agony and are unable to move on from this plane. Bound by a seething, confused hatred to the places where they perished they spend their days looking for humans to endlessly torture with their vicious mockery.

entries.name: Easily Influenced
entries: Due to their undeveloped personalities, their childlike tantrums lead them to lash out at the world without rhyme or reason. This same temperament makes them easily susceptible to the influence of any figure presenting themselves as a parental figure - especially sorcerers, warlocks, and wizards who channel the rage of these fickle fiends.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Hellion Children in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/hellion-child-cmTM1BgZSd}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider Deputy is a 1st-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma. The deputy knows the following spell:

trait.name: Iron Rider's Authority
entries: The Iron Rider Deputy can expend a 1st-level ranger spell slot to imbue themselves with the authority of their station for 1 minute. They gain advantage on any check related to leadership, persuasion, or intimidation.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider Deputy makes two shortsword attacks, provided it has a {@item shortsword|PHB} in each hand.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage, or 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Deputy in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-deputy-S9G0VKvtRB}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider hunter is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom. The hunter knows the following ranger spells:

trait.name: Iron Rider's Awareness
entries: The Iron Rider hunter can expend a 1st-level ranger spell slot to sense for 1 minute whether arcane or innate spellcasters, aberrations, fey, and fiends are within 1 mile. This trait doesn't reveal the creatures' locations or numbers.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider hunter makes two shortsword attacks, provided it has a {@item shortsword|PHB} in each hand.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, ranged 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Hunter in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-hunter-kPxugCHSLi}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider Commodore is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). The commodore has the following paladin spells prepared:

trait.name: Aura of Clarity
entries: While within 10 feet of a conscious Iron Rider commodore, creatures of the commodore's choice can't be {@condition blinded} or {@condition frightened}, and creatures and objects can be {@condition invisible} only if the commodore allows it.

trait.name: Brand Heretic (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: As a bonus action, the Iron Rider commodore chooses one creature the commodore can see within 30 feet of it. The commodore marks the target as a heretic. For 1 minute, the commodore's weapon attack rolls against the heretic score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20. At the start of each of the heretic's turns, the commodore can use a reaction to make one weapon attack against the heretic.

trait.name: Smite
entries: When the Iron Rider commodore hits with a melee weapon attack, it can expend one spell slot to deal extra radiant damage. The extra damage is 9 ({@dice 2d8}) for a 1stlevel spell slot, 13 ({@dice 3d8}) for a 2nd-level one, and 18 ({@dice 4d8}) for a 3rd level slot.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The commodore makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) radiant damage.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The Iron Rider knight has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Discerning
entries: The Iron Rider knight has advantage on saving throws against illusions.

trait.name: Mark
entries: When the Iron Rider knight hits a creature with a melee weapon attack, the knight marks that creature until the end of the knight's next turn. The mark ends early if the knight becomes {@condition incapacitated} or dies, or someone else marks the same creature. While the marked creature is within the knight's reach, it has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than the knight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider knight makes two attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack, and Mark.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage and, if used to make a melee attack, and Mark.

reaction.name: Marked Control
entries: If a creature subjected to the Iron Rider knight's Mark moves while within 5 feet of the knight, the knight can make a melee attack against that creature. On a hit, the creature's speed drops to 0 until the end of their current turn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Deputy in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-knight-JIpk2Tegm7}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider priest is a 6th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Ward
entries: If the Iron Rider priest casts a spell that causes creatures to regain hit points, the priest can also end the effects of one spell affecting one creature that regained hit points. The ended effects must be from a spell of a level equal to or lower than the spell slot the priest used to cast the healing spell.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) bludgeoning damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) force damage, or 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Priest in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-priest-rqFdIU3jmX}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Iron Rider warder is a 12th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following cleric spells prepared:

trait.name: Ward
entries: If the Iron Rider warder casts a spell that causes creatures to regain hit points, the warder can also end the effects of one spell affecting one creature that regained hit points. The ended effects must be from a spell of a level equal to or lower than the spell slot the warder used to cast the healing spell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Iron Rider warder makes two warhammer attacks.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage, or 13 ({@damage 3d8}) force damage if the target is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Iron Rider Warder in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/iron-rider-warder-TQ0pXTDXj0}.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 piercing damage.

{@i Each fall, hunters all over the realm strike out into the forests and hills to pursue this brightly plumed upland game bird. Prized as exceptional tablefare, it often graces the menus of many a tavern}

entries.name: Timothy's Warbler
entries: Named for the {@race Dwarf (Hearth)|dungeonchurch|hearth dwarf} conservationist who spread the bird throughout the lands of Pyora in his travels, the full name is technically {@i Timothy's One-Eyed Purple Breasted Warbler}.

monster.name: Sap Ooze
languages: none in its natural form; knows the same languages as a creature it dominates

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The sap ooze can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Season's Change
entries: If a sap ooze (or its host) takes at least 10 fire damage, it also gains the effect of a {@spell haste} spell until the end of its next turn. If it takes at least 10 cold damage, it gains the effect of a {@spell slow} spell until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sap ooze makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}), and the sap ooze uses Soul Sap on it as a bonus action.

action.name: Soul Sap
entries: The sap ooze slides down the throat of a sleeping, helpless, or {@condition grappled} living creature of Medium size or smaller. Once inside, the sap ooze takes control of its host, as per the dominate monster spell (Wisdom {@dc 12} negates). While dominated, the host gains {@sense blindsight} 90 feet. The host drips blood from its ears, nose, eyes, or from a wound that resembles the injury done to the sap demon's tree (1 damage/Hour). Damage inflicted on the host has no effect on the sap demon. If the host dies or is reduced to 0 hit points, the sap ooze must leave the body within one hour.

{@i When a sap ooze leaves a tree, its milky amber fluid oozes from an axe wound on a stout maple's trunk and shapes itself into a small, vaguely humanoid form on the forest floor beside the tree. This languid creature half walks and half flows forward, implacably following the axe wielder's path to certain revenge.}

entries.name: Tree Oozes
entries: Sap oozes are intelligent oozes that form when an enchanted tree is cut or injured. Though typically Small, the larger the sap source is, the larger the resulting creature can be. Over a few hours, they pool into a shape that vaguely resembles their tree's attacker: for instance, if the tree cutter wore a hat, then a hat may be incorporated into the sap ooze's overall shape. The similarity is faint at best; no one would ever confuse a sap ooze for the creature it hunts, because its shape has no sharp features or color other than amber.

entries.name: Called to Vengeance
entries: Sap oozes can pummel their prey with partially-crystallized fists, but they especially enjoy claiming the weapon that wounded their tree and wielding it to deliver a final blow. Once their prey is destroyed, most sap oozes return to their tree, but not all do. Some are curious or malevolent enough to explore the world further.

entries.name: Reckless Possessors
entries: A sap ooze can possess another creature by grappling it and oozing down its throat. Once inside, the sap ooze dominates its host and makes it bleed as the tree bled. Since the sap ooze takes no damage when its host is wounded, it's free to be as reckless as it likes. It might wander into a town to cause trouble. However, no matter how its new body is bandaged or cured, it never stops bleeding slowly. If the host body is killed, the sap oozes out during the next hour and either returns to its tree or seeks another host.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Sap Ooze in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sap-ooze-eGVX8QPLEh}.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The scorchcock has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Peck
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.

action.name: Fire Crow (Recharge 5-6)
entries: The scorchcock exhales fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 13 (3d8) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Scorchcock in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/scorchcock-s33IndCpN3}.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The vomit ooze can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Drunken Miasma
entries: Creatures that start their turn within 10 feet of the ooze that can smell it must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw. If the creature fails, it takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition intoxicated|dungeonchurch} for {@dice 1d4} rounds.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The vomit ooze can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Alcohol-Infused Pseudopod {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or its Intelligence score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Intelligence to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

reaction.name: Split
entries: When a vomit ooze is subject to slashing damage, it splits into two new oozes if it has at least 10 HP. Each new ooze has HP equal to half the original ooze's, rounded down. New oozes are one size smaller than the original ooze.

reaction.name: Last Call
entries: When the vomit ooze is reduced to 0 hit points, it releases a final, noxious belch of reflux at the creature that dealt the killing blow. That creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.
You ever pound gl√∂g until you puke your brains out? Then you've never partied at the {@link Skull & Sword|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/skull-sword-tavern-iojXWZVPWD}.

Vomit oozes are spontaneous arcane accidents--born from a particularly potent mixture of booze, {@table Pyoran Substances|dungeonchurch|illicit magical intoxication}, and emotional instability. When a magically inclined individual overindulges and loses their stomach in a dingy alley, there's a small chance that the expelled mess keeps the party going... mindlessly seeking out more alcohol and the opportunity for a brawl.

entries.name: Urban Hazard
entries: Often mistaken for spilled chamber pots or rotting garbage, vomit oozes lurk in alleys, sewers, or near taverns of ill repute. While slow moving and unintelligent, when provoked they respond with drunken rage.

entries.name: Ooze Nature
entries: A vomit ooze doesn't require sleep, air, or food but consuming more alcohol makes it grow larger in size and more chaotic in temperament. It will seek out anything that smells of booze, including recent imbibers.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Vomit Ooze in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/vomit-ooze-DhW28eyxrK}.

trait.name: Keen Smell and Touch
entries: The zombie raccoon has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell or touch.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the zombie raccoon to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie raccoon drops to 1 hit point instead.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The zombie raccoon has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the raccoon's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage.

Once ordinary raccoons known for their curiosity and social behavior, these creatures have fallen victim to the scourge of undeath. Most Zombie Raccoons are transformed after scavenging on the remains of other undead creatures, consuming flesh that taints them. This transformation twists their natural instincts and chaotic nature into a more malevolent form.

entries.name: Social Scavengers
entries: Zombie raccoons often roam in packs, which makes them especially dangerous to livestock and humans alike. Their relentless hunger for flesh drives them to work together on ever more clever escapades, coordinating attacks with chilling cunning. Being one of the few animals other than primates to possess opposable thumbs, they have been known to work locks, doors, and set traps that belies their humble origins.

entries.name: Undead Warning
entries: The presence of Zombie Raccoons is often a herald of greater undead activity in the area. As they scavenge what is available, they unwittingly become spreaders of the corruption and quickly throw natural ecosystems out of balance.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Zombie Raccoon in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/zombie-raccoon-kRMzfO1jg9}.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The zombie vulture doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The zombie vulture has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The zombie vulture has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the vulture's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zombie vulture makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage. The target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution save. On a failed save, the target takes poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The afflicted can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

The once majestic vulture now lurches through the air with a grotesque, jerking motion. Ragged feathers cling to its rotting wings and the putrid stench of decay follows in its wake. It's natural appetite has betrayed it, becoming twisted and consumed by the things it once devoured. These undead birds congregate in sickening flocks, circling hungrily over the dead and living alike.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Zombie Vulture in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/zombie-vulture-Uc0z6ODNRp}.

item.name: Abi-Tseos's Machete
item.reqAttune: by reading the scrawled phrase on the hilt.
entries: You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. In addition, the weapon ignores resistance to slashing damage and deals an extra {@dice 2d8} slashing damage to plants and Plant creatures.

The 17-inch blade of this tool-weapon appears deceptively dull and chipped, its hilt is carved azabache (a mystical stone believed to ward off malevolent spirits), and its handle is carved with a disturbing depiction of writhing, bloated leeches. The bohika (shaman) after which the weapon is named used it to wantonly cut down selva and conduct excessive ritual sacrifice to their patron. A lock of unmarred blonde hair dangles from the pommel, its significance lost to time. If the blade is held at the right angle in light, a scrawled phrase appears on the hilt: {@i A mi, volpal} which translates from its indigenous tongue as {@i A blade for me.}

When you attack a creature that has at least one head with this weapon and roll a 20 on the attack roll, you cut off one of the creatures heads. The creature dies if it can't survive without the lost head. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to slashing damage, doesn't have or need a head, has legendary actions, or the DM decides the creature is too big for its head to be cut off with this weapon. Such a creature takes an extra {@dice 6d8} slashing damage from the hit.

entries.name: Cursed
entries: Whenever you deal damage with Abi-Teos's machete, you take {@dice 1d6} necrotic damage as the weapon drains your blood. If you roll a 1 on an attack roll made with the weapon, the leeches carved into the handle animate and crawl down your throat--infesting you with throat leeches (a disease). You must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of exhaustion that can only be removed by succeeding on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw upon completing a long rest. If the saving throw fails, you gain another level of exhaustion. If a successful saving throw reduces your exhaustion level below 1, you recover from the disease.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Abi-Tseos's Machete in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/abi-teoss-machete-ZrSq7FcMTj}.

item.name: Amulet of Betrayal
entries: You can use a bonus action to move one of the following conditions from yourself to an ally within 60 feet of you: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition poisoned}, {@condition stunned}, {@condition exhaustion}. When transferring {@condition exhaustion}, move all your {@condition exhaustion} levels. If the chosen ally is immune to a transferred condition, the transfer fails.

This item was once owned by the vampire knight {@link Lamont Solmar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}, who served the {@link Lady Nightshade|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lady-nightshade-3kjLNj2Zbs}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Amulet of Betrayal in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/amulet-of-betrayal-vY1rCwAwHh}.

item.name: Amulet of False Life
entries: A black stone pendant chiseled into an eye on a silver chain which is cold to the touch.
Once per long rest, the wearer can cast {@spell False Life} at 2nd level ({@dice 1d4+9}).

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Amulet of False Life in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/amulet-of-false-life-vuSsCyR2g0}.

fluff.name: Amulet of False Life
entries: The dark radiant eye is the symbol of the {@link Eye of Duskmire|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/eye-of-duskmire-zVMHbvUlGR}, a powerful dhampir estate that advises the {@link Crimson Court|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/crimson-court-cofX8ha90z}.

item.name: Animated Peanuts
entries: A paper bag of {@dice 1d6} roasted, sentient peanuts. The salty peanuts have a profound hatred of mortals. The snacker may use an action to eat one, allowing them to cast {@spell Vicious Mockery} on a target of their choice.

item.name: Avalon Engineer's Signet
entries: This gilded ring bears a beautiful engraving of a gear and is imbued with the elven magic of {@link Avalon|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalon-7amKaC2AMg}. While wearing this ring, you can use an action to cast the {@spell Mending} and {@spell Arcane Lock} spells once each using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. Once you use the ring to cast the spells, the ring can't be used again until the next dawn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Avalon Engineer's Signet in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalon-engineers-signet-63RXQwAWMe}.

item.name: Avalonian Lantern
entries: This elven {@item bullseye lantern|phb} contains a shard of magic crystal that sheds light comparable to that produced by a {@spell continual flame} spell. The lantern is activated by pushing a button on it's side that initiates a series of mechanical gears that perform the spell as a ritual. An Avalonian lantern sheds light in a 120-foot cone; the closest 60 feet is bright light, and the farthest 60 feet is dim light.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Avalonian Lantern in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/avalonian-lantern-4rhyHvymXn}.

item.name: Bag of Alligator Tongues
entries: This grubby bag of alligator tongues contains several dessicated reptile tongues that look like crawling worms. Consuming the tongues causes the eater to increase by {@table Size Categories|MM|two sizes}.

item.name: Bag of Rust
entries: This ordinary leather bag appears empty. Reaching inside the bag, however, reveals a handful of rust powder.

Once a day, you can use an action to pull rust powder from the bag and throw it up to 20 feet. The powder cloud transforms into a creature you determine by rolling a {@dice d8} and consulting the table.

The creature is friendly to you and your companions, and it acts on your turn. You can use a bonus action to command how the creature moves and what action it takes on its next turn, or to give it general orders, such as to attack your enemies. In the absence of such orders, the creature acts in a fashion appropriate to its nature.
Creatures summoned this way are resistant to necrotic damage.
The creature vanishes at the next dawn or when it is reduced to 0 hit points. At that point, the bag can be used again.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Bag of Rust in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/bag-of-rust-SfaknUwwtp}.

item.name: Banshee Blight
entries: Illicit street drug made of ground silvery bark from a type of tree only found deep in swamps. Low dosages are generally taken orally. Heavier users often make a paste to apply to their gums. Addicts may smear it into cuts. Potent stimulant that gives users an adrenaline rush and time seems to slow down, but the duration of the high is short.  Can cause psychosis. Death comes from heart failure, wound infection, self-neglect, or wild magic shock in susceptible individuals. Psychologically addictive not physically.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Banshee Blight in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/banshee-blight-ziIwCBr2jq}.

item.name: Berserker's Draught
entries: A carbonated and heavily hopped brew contained in a bottle crafted from thick, unpolished amber glass. Instead of a brewer's mark, the glass is crudely etched by hand with the dwarven rune for berserker.

When you drink this beer, you feel the heightened awareness and confidence of an experienced brawler flood through you for 5 minutes. When attacking with an unarmed strike or improvised weapon, you have advantage on the attack roll and can use your bonus action to make another attack of the same type. Your heightened battle focus gives you disadvantage on Wisdom and Intelligence checks and saving throws.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Berserker's Draught in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/berserkers-draught-sn5rNNx4Lp}.

fluff.name: Berserker's Draught
entries: While not commercially available, the breweries of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} are known for producing all types of experimental concoctions off-label. Variations on the berserker's draught recipe are unique to each brewer and a closely held secret.

item.name: Black Diamond
entries: Illicit street drug magically synthesized from volcanic rock, giving it the appearance of a gray or black crystal. Low dosages are generally smoked in a glass pipe. Addicts may crush it and smear it into cuts. The potent opioid gives users a full-bodied sense of euphoria and brings pain levels down to zero. Death comes from respiratory failure, wound infection and necrosis, and self-neglect. Severely physically addictive. Magic users are immune to its effects.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Black Diamond in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/black-diamond-pTSDpxQOJ4}.

item.name: Blacklung Brew
entries: A black lager brewed with traces of coal dust, it has a deep charcoal color and smoky aftertaste. Originally crafted by dwarven miners to build resistance to the toxic gases found deep underground.
When you drink this brew, you gain resistance to poison damage for 1 hour. Additionally, you have advantage on saving throws against inhaled toxins.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Blacklung Brew in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/blacklung-brew-SzL7h3Wqun}.

fluff.name: Blacklung Brew
entries: Durandian miners swear by Blacklung Brew, believing it not only fortifies their lungs against foul air but also enhances their ability to work for longer hours in the deepest tunnels.

item.name: Brooch of Witchsight
entries: This ornate brooch is crafted from a dark metal clutching its centerpiece gem - a mesmerizing sapphire that pulses with a spectral light. Inside the gem is a crystalized, unblinking human eyeball - about the size of a child's.

entries.name: Witchsight
entries: While wearing and attuned to the brooch, the wearer gains {@variantrule Witchsight|dungeonchurch} and can see magical ley lines as glowing paths or streams of energy that traverse the land within a range of 100'.

entries.name: Navigate the Arcane
entries: The wearer gains advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks made to navigate or understand the properties of magical locations, including detecting the presence of nearby portals, enchantments, or areas of strong magical influence.

entries.name: Attunement
entries: To attune to the brooch, you must spend a Long Rest meditating on the arcane in an area where ley lines are present.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Brooch of Witchsight in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/brooch-of-witchsight-Do7tfU7V9e}.

item.name: Boot of Beer
entries: This ordinary looking dwarven boot appears to be able to hold about a gallon of liquid.
You can use an action to roll a random draught from the table below, causing the boot to produce that liquid.
Afterward, you can pour that liquid out as an action, up to 2 gallons per minute.
Once the boot starts producing a liquid, it can't produce a different one until the next dawn.

item.name: Bottled Sarlacc Pheromones
entries: This bottle contains sarlacc pheromones. When poured on the ground, a sarlacc pit appears with a diameter of 30' and is difficult terrain.
Creatures who move into or start their turn in the sarlacc pit must make a DC 14 Strength saving throw or be pulled 10' further into the pit.
If the creature is pulled into the center of the pit, it takes {@dice 2d6} piercing damage and is {@condition grappled} by the sarlacc.

item.name: Boots of Black Ice
entries: While you wear these boots, you can use an action to create a slippery path of black ice along the path of your movement this turn. The ice melts at the end of your next turn.
The black ice is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. When a creature steps onto the ice for the first time or starts its turn there, it must make a DC 15 Dexterity save or fall {@condition prone}.

If a creature starts its turn in the spell's area and is {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell, the creature must make a successful Constitution saving throw or lose {@status concentration}.

item.name: Cirilla's Gift
entries: Cirilla's gift is a ring that was worn by the elven battle mage {@link Cirilla of Avalon|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cirrilla-of-house-naberius-Rx97WvltxP} during the Dragon Wars. After facing a series of defeats on the open battle field, a small group of allies brought the war to the dragon's den. Amongst these was the future dragonborn leader {@link Razorback|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/razorback-the-uniter-O3oe7NBQqK}.

In an attempt to ambush the dragon, Cirilla sacrificed her life in order to save the lives of her friends and defeat the dragon. This set off a cascade of magical effects that resulted in an explosion so powerful that a piece of Cirilla's soul became embedded in the ring, thus imbuing it with its potent and volatile properties.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Cirilla's Gift in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cirillas-gift-pKEY4nYJDS}.

item.name: Cloak of Rats
entries: This hooded cloak is made from hundreds of rough leather rat skins, stitched together with twine, and fringed with dessicated rat tails. Wearing this rancid smelling cloak gives the wearer +1 to Constitution saves and allows the attuned wearer to {@spell polymorph} into a {@creature rat} once a day.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Cloak of Rats in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/cloak-of-rats-iHIvQwaOt1}.

item.name: Collector of Souls
entries: A black obsidian pyramid covered in runes. Said to be activated by the fresh blood of a dragon, by which it gains the power to collect and free the souls of the draconic damned.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Collector of Souls in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/collector-of-souls-XA0hpJ7gfE}.

Said to have been created by {@link Proteus|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/proteus-Apiz4CreFn}, the sahuagin used it as a {@link payment for the illicit arms|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/session-12-13-the-forge-of-fury-m1dOelbiNy#h-the-deal} the gnomes manufactured using the {@link abandoned dwarven forge|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-old-mine-ndIfgvk1B6} near {@link Saltmarsh|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/saltmarsh-GkGI6ISio5}.

It later reappeared when a {@link gnomish company|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/the-sunless-temple-1-nine-of-cups-cBaQBejsRH} was tasked with clearing a section of the {@link Sunless Temple|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/sunless-temple-yS5i3gqWiO} that was leaking monsters and mayhem into their {@link Underdark|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/underdark-Lu1sEFgEWw} territory.

Adventurers associated with the {@link Gold Scale Co.|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/gold-scale-company-m1WdlmIYwP} received this relic from the gnomes in the Temple and used it to free the dragonborn souls enslaved by the {@link Knight of Night|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lamont-solmar-GLrWBoIX5h}.

item.name: Dagger of Profuse Bleeding
entries: This obsidian dagger has a wicked, serrated edge to it that rends flesh as it cuts.

entries.name: Wicked Edge
entries: When you hit a creature with this magic weapon, it causes the target to bleed profusely at even the slightest injury. Because of the amount of blood, they are unable to heal themselves by medicine or magic on their next turn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dagger of Profuse Bleeding in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dagger-of-profuse-bleeding-uXUIGCXKkL}.

item.name: Dark Truth Serum
entries: A creature subjected to this poison must succeed on a DC Constitution 16 save or be afflicted by terrifying hallucinations for 1 hour.

During this time, they suffer disadvantage on all skill checks and saving throws due to the overwhelming visions. If they survive the hour, they gain a flash of insight: they may ask one question (as though using the {@spell Commune} spell) or recall a hidden or forgotten truth relevant to their current situation. They then suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dark Truth Serum in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/serum-of-dark-truth-XpjnKHYKML}.
This subtly glowing crimson liquid is a powerful and dangerous potion. Said to be brewed from adrenalized blood under a full moon, it reveals deep, hidden truths--but at a terrifying cost.
It is rumored that it is used to enhance interrogations or reveal dangerous knowledge quickly. Some are known to use it on themselves in pursuit of their own repressed secrets.

item.name: Deepgarden Cider
entries: A crisp, mildly tart cider brewed from rare subterranean apples, cultivated carefully within the underground arks of the {@link Arkwrights Guild|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/arkwrights-guild-xpUNyD7GMm}.
When consumed during a short rest, this cider revitalizes you, reducing the required duration of the rest by half. This benefit can be gained only once per long rest.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Deepgarden Cider in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/deepgarden-cider-5Q8snj1J61}.

fluff.name: Deepgarden Cider
entries: Deep beneath the bustling forges and grand halls of {@link Durandar|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/durandar-sWDxZHDVIC} lie the carefully tended "arks" of the {@link Arkwrights Guild|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/arkwrights-guild-xpUNyD7GMm}, subterranean gardens where the guild's Curators nurture rare plants and fruits from across Pyora. Among these are special orchards of Deepgarden Apples, small fruits with shimmering golden skin adapted to thrive solely beneath the earth, nourished by the bioluminescent glow of specific fungi. These apples, when pressed and fermented, produce Deepgarden Cider, a staple beverage common on every menu and dinner table across Durandar.

item.name: Delerium-Forged Dagger
entries: This dagger has a small delerium sliver encased in glass and set in the hilt like a gemstone. The blade is made of meteoric iron infused with delerium dust, which causes it to softly glow with octarine light.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon.

When you make an attack with this dagger, you can use your spellcasting ability modifier, instead of Strength or Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls. In addition, you can use this weapon as a spellcasting focus.

When you roll a 20 on an attack roll made with this weapon against a humanoid, the humanoid must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take an extra ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage and gain one {@adventure level of contamination|DoDk|12}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Delerium-Forged Dagger in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/delerium-forged-dagger-5OshXhJW5D}.

item.name: Dimensional Glasses
entries: A set of glasses that look like a kaleidoscope from the outside. Looking through them shows vignettes of various planes of existence regularly swapping, overlayed onto the environment around you. They can also be held in place by a switch, useful for creatures feeling homesick.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Dimensional Glasses in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dimensional-glasses-953LlRzRKE}.

item.name: Dream Vine
entries: A fragrant herb often smoked in pipes or hand rolled cigarettes, it has a mild stimulant effect said to encourage conversation and the free flow of ideas. It's use varies widely by cultural norms. Strictly forbidden in {@link Striborg|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/striborg-mZk9jSyJUV} as an illicit narcotic, it is commonly smoked as part of the cafe culture in {@link New Galmaarden|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/new-galmaarden-03tcpxxc2t}.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Dream Vine in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dream-vine-viEBw5FxT7}.

item.name: Dubbelheart Ale
entries: A rich, deep amber dubbel-style ale brewed by the forgemasters of Durandar. The yeast used in its fermentation thrives in the intense heat of dwarven hearths & forges, developing a distinct spicy-herbal character with undertones of clove, coriander, and roasted malt.
When you drink this ale, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Constitution modifier + 2 (minimum of 3).
Additionally, for 10 minutes, you become extra sure-footed - granting you advantage on checks and saving throws against being knocked prone or forcibly moved.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Dubbelheart Ale in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/dubbelheart-ale-hhJAx5QaAA}.

fluff.name: Dubbelheart Ale
entries: The forgemasters of Durandar keep the recipe close among their own, believing that the unqiue spice blend with the heat of the hearth imparts not just flavor, but fortitude. It is often shared before long journeys, coming of age celebrations, or dangerous battles, ensuring that a dwarf's heart burns as strong as their forge.

item.name: Dust of Deliciousness
entries: The Dust of Deliciousness is a reddish-brown dust that, when sprinkled on any edible substance, greatly improves the flavor. It also dulls the senses of the consumer, giving them disadvantage on wisdom-based checks and saves for one hour.

item.name: Faerie Fire Grenade
entries: As an action, a character can throw a grenade at a point up to 60 feet away. With a grenade launcher, the character can propel the grenade up to 120 feet away.
One round after a stink grenade lands, it explodes and creates {@spell faerie fire}.

item.name: Eclipse Lantern
entries: This elegant, elven {@item bullseye lantern|PHB} is masterfully crafted from metal and etched with delicate runes. A crystal shard is embedded in it's mechanism in place of a wick, which focuses and projects darkness comparable to that produced by a {@spell Darkness} spell.

The user can perform a ritual to charge the lantern by turning a clockwork key on it's side for at least 1 minute. Once charged, the lantern can be activated using an action to press a button creating a 30 foot cone of magical darkness The darkness persists for 10 minutes, or until the lanternet is closed. Once activated, the ritual cannot be repeated until the next dawn.

item.name: Entrancing Mirror
entries: These small, handheld mirrors project an inviting, soft blue glow from their surface. When a creature gazes into the mirror, they are presented with a convincing, but distorted, view of themselves and their place in the world. Creatures who gaze habitually into the entrancing mirror come to be susceptible to internalizing it's false reflection.

For this reason, entrancing mirrors are usually created by unscrupulous warlocks or narcissistic artificers who put them out into the world to feed on the life force that the gazers put into the mirrors. With enough entrancing mirrors in circulation, some of these dark practitioners are able to influence entire populations and thus bend reality closer to the false reflections they conjure.

entries.name: Creeping Influence
entries: Each time a creature gazes into the entrancing mirror, they learn something new, interesting, or delightful but must make a DC 10 Intelligence saving throw. After accumulating 3 fails, they start to identify with the desires of the entrancing mirror's creator and come under the influence of a {@spell Suggestion} spell. This effect lasts 72 hours, and each subsequent use of the mirror extends this period another 72 hours.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Entrancing Mirror in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/entrancing-mirror-LEDVsFaum5}.

item.name: Essence of Submission
entries: An amber colored liquid with a honey-like viscosity and a sweet taste that masks it's true purpose. The main ingredients are a mix of herbs known for their hypnotic effects combined with {@creature vampire} saliva.
When consumed, it instills a deep sense of trust and submission making the drinker obedient to those around them.
The target must make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} into a suggestible state for 1 hour. The charm breaks if the target's trust is betrayed while under the influence.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about {@link Essence of Submission in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/essence-of-submission-U5IGAEmwpH}.

Essence of Submission is used by the vampires of {@link Duskmire|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/duskmire-hJey19lfsu} as a method of social control of the humans they keep for their blood quota. While the high walls of the dark city keep both humans and vampires under the watchful eye of {@link Lady Nightshade|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/lady-nightshade-3kjLNj2Zbs}, the real trap for the humans is laid in their minds slowly over time as they are acclimated to their fate.

item.name: Fedora of Disguise
entries: This hat is patched together out of a motley of many colors and types of materials, forming it into a lumpy fedora shape head covering.
While wearing this fedora, you can use an action to cast the {@spell disguise self} spell from it once a day. The spell ends if the hat is removed. The hat's potential renews at dawn.

entries.name: Dungeon Church Lore
entries: Learn more about the {@link Fedora of Disguise in the wiki|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/fedora-of-disguise-c7i4G0ePRf}.

item.name: Fist of Durradin
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon, and it deals double damage to objects and structures.

A mythical flail forged by the dwarves long ago. It is said to be modeled after the hand of {@link King Durradin|https://lore.dungeon.church/doc/king-durradin-SGe3lRM9BN}, though there is no record of the king himself wielding the weapon in battle. Still, the weight of the flail feels light and easy to wield for how heavy it weighs on the scale compared to stone or iron of equal portion.

entries.name: POW!
